snippet: Once a person has been convicted, even on unimaginably shaky grounds, an almost inexorable process — one that ends in execution — is set in motion.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Raymond Bonner, lawyer and author, highlights the false conviction of Edward Lee Elmore, who has been released from prison after serving 11,000 days in jail; argues that Elmore's case illustrates how difficult it is to exonerate a falsely convicted person because it is presumed that the defendant has had a fair trial.
lead_paragraph: Once a person has been convicted, even on unimaginably shaky grounds, an almost inexorable process — one that ends in execution — is set in motion.
